loans.name: Dousoussouma Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Dousoussouma sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 38ans et 5 enfants et ont toutes des coépouses. Elles vivent dans le village de TDJILA, sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali.
 Elles font le commerce d’articles divers tels la vente de soumbala, de condiments alimentaires, d’arachide, des légumes et la restauration.
Elles sont à leur première prêt (prêt solidaire) et comptent l’utiliser pour acheter,  7 sacs de céréales et d’arachide, 100 kilogrammes de grains de Néré pour faire le soumbala, 5 sacs de légumes et divers  condiments. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de NIENA, et de TDJILA. Les marchandises sont vendues en détail et au comptant au marché de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA et celui de NIEN à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The ten women in the Dousoussouma group are all married and have co-spouses. They average 38 years of age and 5 children. They live in the village of Tdjila, in the Niena subprefecture, third administrative region of Mali. Their businesses consist in selling diverse items such as soumbala (a traditional condiment made out of Néré seeds), food condiments, peanuts, vegetables, as well as in food serving.

They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan) and intend to use it to buy 7 sacks of cereals and peanuts, 100 kilograms of Néré seeds to make soumbala, 5 sacks of vegetables and various condiments. The get their supplies at the Niena and Tdjila markets. The goods are retailed for cash at the Niena, Bougoulaba and Nien markets, to a clientele comprising men and women.

They foresee to turn a monthly profit of XOF 5'000 (ca US$ 10) each, to be in part used to provide for their families, and in part invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items (cereals, peanuts, vegetables, ...)

loans.name: Assiba

texts.fr:
Originaire de Ketou un petit village du département de Sèmè Podji situé à 10 Km de la ville de Porto-Novo la capitale politique du BENIN. D. Assiba est agée de 65 ans. Mariée à ATALE Léonel un peintre bâtiment de profession, Assiba est mère de 6 enfants tous majeurs. Assiba vit à Cotonou au quartier AGBODJEDO où elle vendait il y a 10 ans du poisson fumé. Mais depuis 5 ans maintenant Assiba a laissé cette activité au profit de la vente du  haricot en détail et du sodabi, une boisson locale alcoolisée et très appréciée du peuple béninois. Ses clients potentiels sont les restaurateurs à qui Assiba livre surtout cette boisson. Assiba va régulièrement s'approvisionner dans les villages à l'interieur du Bénin. Aujourd'hui Assiba a deux de ses petits fils à sa charge et elle dépense en moyenne 1500 F par jour pour nourrir sa famille. La demande de ses produits est très forte sur le marché. C'est pourquoi D. Assiba demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer ses activités. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour ses clients. 
 

i
texts.en:
Having roots in Ketou, a small village in Sèmè Podji County (located 10 km from the city of Porto-Novo, the political capital of BENIN), Ms. D. Assiba, age 65, is married to Mr. ATALE Léonel, a house painter by profession. Assiba is the mother of six children, all of age. She lives in Cotonou in the AGBODJEDO district, where she used to sell smoked fish ten years ago. But five years ago, she dropped that business in favor of retail sales in beans and sodabi, a local alcoholic drink that is highly appreciated by the people of Benin. Her potential customers are restauranteurs to whom Assiba makes deliveries, especially this drink. She regularly goes to get supplies from inland villages of Benin. Today, she supports two of her grand-daughters and spends 1,500 francs on average each day to feed her family. The market demand for her merchandise is very strong. That’s why she’s requesting a third loan, so as to bolster her business. Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for its clients.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 50-kg sacks of beans and a 50-liter drum of sodabi

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys, 42 years old and married with two children, rears and sells birds.  Residing in Delta State, Nigeria, she has been in this business for many years and is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more birds to sell. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more birds to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth C. has enjoyed more than a year of association with Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative, a partner through thick and thin for her business. Her primary source of income is selling used clothing. It’s a daily challenge for her to submit her loan payments on time, but this has now become a habit. Elizabeth is 57 years old, married, and has eight children. She tells us with pride that she is able to nurture all her children well. Finishing a degree was far out of sight for her and she only reached the fourth year high school. But, she’s happy that she was able to send her children to school. In fact, she has now children working abroad. She has applied with Paglaum MPC for a loan of PHP 40,000. With this loan she will purchase additional bundles of used clothing. She wants to expand her business by opening another used clothing store.

loans.use: Buy bundles of used clothing

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia es socia del Banco Comunal Muchuy Huaraqac que significa abundancia en quechua.
Antonia es casada, tiene 62 años, Antonia viaja a las ferias en donD. compra ganado que luego venD. en la feria D. San Juan, en algunas oportunidades mata los animales y los comercializa D. casa en casa. Además Antonia se dedica al engorD. D. ganado.
Antonia necesita un préstamo D. 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. ganado para engorD..
Los sueños D. Antonia son mejorar su negocio y ahorrar para el futuro.
texts.en:
Antonia is a member of the collective Banco Comunal Muchuy Huaraqac, which means "abundance" in Quechua. She is 62 years old and married. Antonia travels to markets where she purchases livestock to sell at the San Juan Market. Sometimes she slaughters the animals and sells the meat door-to-door. She also fattens livestock. Antonia needs a loan of 1200 soles to invest in livestock for fattening. Her dreams incluD. improving her business and saving for the future.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in livestock for fattening up.

loans.name: Rita Liseth

texts.es: Rita Lisseth esta solicitando refinanciamiento de su 2do crédito para construir una habitacion, labora desde hace 2 años como docente de Educación primaria, inicio dando clase a niños de un centro infantil en la zona # 7 de Nueva Guinea; Rita  es madre de un niño de 2 añitos de edad, a pesar que no tiene la ayuda del papa de su hijo ha luchado para que a el no le falte nada, se caracteriza por ser una buena maestra, humilde,  responsable, honesta y muy trabajadora, despues que llega de dar clases termina de hacer los quehaceres del hogar ya que su salario es poco y no le alcanza para pagar una empleada domestica, con este pretende contruir un cuarto y asi mejorar sus condiciones de vida y de su familia, actualmente esta estudiando su segundo año en ciencias de la Educacion en la Universidad URACCAN,  su sueño es seguir estudiando, ir mejorando su vivienda con cada crédito otorgado por AFODENIC, salud para su familia y estabilidad laboral.
texts.en:
Rita Lisseth is requesting refinancing of her 2nd loan to build a room. She has been working for 2 years as an elementary school teacher. She began teaching children at a children's center in zone #7 of Nueva Guinea. Rita is a mother of a 2 year-old boy and in spite of not receiving support from the boy's father she has struggled to fulfill his needs. She is a good teacher, humble, responsible, honest, and very hard-working. After teaching she does her chores as her salary is low and she cannot affort to pay domestic help. With the loan she will build a room to improve her family's living conditions. At the present she is studying the second year of Science of Education at the university URACCAN. It is her dream to continue studying, improve her house with each loan from AFODENIC, health for her family, and work stability.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a room.

loans.name: Miss. Kakda Sun Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank, which consists of sixteen members, is located in Chrouy Ampil village in Kandal province. They plan to use the loan, which they obtained, for different purposes. Miss Kakda S. is the village bank president, as selected by the members. She is single and lives with a large famiL.. She owns a small business making kramars (traditional shawls) to sell. Since her business is doing well, she has a lot of consumers with many demands. Miss Kakda S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk to make more kramars to sell so that she can earn more income to support her famiL..

loans.use: To purchase silks to make traditional kramar shawls.

loans.name: Saili

texts.en:
Saili S., 41, is married with five children. She is in the plantation business and sells to the public and village people four days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala.

She has no previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Saili’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a knapsack sprayer, knives, chemicals, seeds, spade, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expand business/ buy livestock

loans.name: Fiva

texts.en:
Fiva L. (0) is a 50-year-old woman living in the town of Moataa. She is married and has four adult children.

Fiva owns and operates a handicraft business, selling general handicrafts to tourists and local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 300 WST a month.

In 2001, Fiva joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,500 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional handicrafts to sell.

Fiva is now requesting a new loan of 3,000 WST which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. The loan will be her 8th from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Roseline sells drinks, breads and other items. She is 49 years old and married with three children. She lives in Benin City. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 60000 NGN to purchase more drinks and also bush meat to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and also bush meat to sell

loans.name: G.s. Las Flores Gonzalez Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Las F. González está conformado por Julia Maria González F. y Lilliam del Carmen González F.. Ambas tienen diferentes actividades económicas. Doña Julia se dedica a la venta de ropa, y lo hace con mucho esfuerzo para mantener a su familia. Lilliam se dedica a la venta de tortillas. Hace más de 18 años que se dedica a este negocio. En cambio Julia tiene 20 años que se dedica a este negocio pero le gustaría trabajar más horas y así generar ingresos para su familia. El financiamiento que solicitan es para capital de trabajo ya que ambos necesitan invertir en sus negocios. El sueño de ambas es salir adelante con sus negocios y lograr grandes mejorías en sus viviendas.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga B. is from the village of Brgy.4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old, married and has one school-aged child. Dominga has owned and operated a dried fish market for over four years and it is her main source of income. Dominga earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from her market.

In 2009, Dominga joined HSPFI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities through their financial services offerings. Dominga is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to reinvest her profits to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Pich B., 26, is single and resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with his sister (pictured). To make a living, he purchases chickens from local farmers in his province to resell, earning an income of US $5 per day in revenue. His sister is responsible for transporting the chickens to sell at the market, earning an income of US $3.5 per day. They try to work hard every day to ensure a good living for their family. B. is seeking to improve his business, so he is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase more chickens to expand his business. By doing so, he hopes he will be able to generate more income to keep investing in his business and save more money for future household use.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Ochirbat

texts.en:
Ochirbat D. is a 38-year-old single mother who lives in the Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia with her six children. She and her children all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her two youngest daughters currently attend secondary school, and her two young sons, ages 4 and 2, haven't yet started kindergarten. 

D. operates a small sewing business in her town. She repairs and produces a variety of clothing items for her customers at a small rented workspace. Ochirbat started her sewing business in 2003 by herself, but has partnered with her older sister since 2005. Her business is very important for her and her family as it is their only source of income. She has worked hard and found some success, but struggles to support all of her children. 

For the future, Ochirbat hopes to progress her business and says, "I hope to one day own my own workspace." She is requesting a 450,000 tugrug loan to purchase fabrics and materials for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials for her sewing business

loans.name: Norvelyn

texts.en:
Norvelyn A., 44, is married to Leo A., who is a tricycle operator. They live in the village of Calao East, Santiago City. The couple are blessed with two children: Julius, a 19-year-old college undergraduate, and Jay Vee, a 14-year-old who is presently enrolled in high school. Norvelyn and her husband really value education, but due to financial constraint their eldest child was forced to stop his studies. They do wish that he will be able to continue his schooling someday.

Norvelyn is a vegetable vendor in the village. She sells sprouted mongo and has her own plot of sprouted mongo at her house. She would like to improve her business by asking for additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to 4,000 PHP. This would mean a lot to her, especially to help meet her family's needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for business development

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fruit to expand the business.

loans.name: Susan Wanjiru

texts.en:
Susan is 29 years old and married to James. They have one daughter. Susan was introduced to Kadet through an existing client. She has no loan history with another micro-finance institution.

She has been operating a retail shop for the past six months and also does farming as another source of income. She plans to use her loan to add stock to her retail shop: kerosene, charcoal and other general merchandise. She intends expand her retail shop with the extra profit generated from the business. Her dream is to become a charcoal supplier and own her own kerosene pump. She describes herself as an honest and a faithful lady.

loans.use: To add stock to her retail shop (kerosene, charcoal and other general merchandise items)

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a businesswoman. She trades in Dumas clothes, linen and lace materials. She sells mostly through hawking. Her personal selling method, she says, makes her goods move very fast.  She is 55 years old and married. She is mother to six children.  All of her children are currently in school. She is very supportive to her family through her trading business. She takes delivery of goods from Kumasi and retails to her customers. She has been in business for the past seven years, while taking care of her family. She hopes the loan will enable her to reinforce her business and to make more viable profit. She wants to buy more goods so that she can take advantage, over this Christmas, to increase her sales and, hence, her profit margin. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase bulk  Dumas clothes to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Romy

texts.en:
Romy O. is from the village of Lower Langcangan in Oroquieta City. He is 31 years old. Romy is married. To make a living, Romy works in someone else's business providing transportation services to local community members. Romy has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Romy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romy is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be Romy's first loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Set up his workshop and buy a sewing machine

loans.name: We Go Able Group

texts.en: Pictured here are members of the We Go Able group from the small-town of Waterloo, about 26 miles away from Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. The leader of the group is Mohamed S. in the left of the photo. Born in a small-town call Lunsar in northern Sierra Leone, the 40-year-old has been a businessman for more than 25 years. He sells building materials – cement, zinc, etc. in Waterloo. Mohamed is married to a businesswoman and they have 19 children. Mohamed will use this loan to further expand his business; he will use the loan to buy building materials to add to his business.

loans.use: Buy house building materials to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is a 45-year-old married woman with five children aged from 10 to 16 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she lives with seven people. The family has access to electricity and piped water at her home and gets three meals a day.

Eva resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She sells yellow bananas in Nakawa market in one of the Kampala suburbs. She sells to an average of twenty people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work from suppliers who get their supplies from villages. Her major monthly expenses include medication, rent for her business, and feeding the family.

Eva has been in this business for the last seven years and has been with MCDT for over six years. She is servicing her fourteenth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.

Eva is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and offloading a full lorry (truckload) of bananas.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhoeun Saing Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has fifteen people who are villagers in Ta Ou Khang Cheung Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Sokhoeun S. is a village bank president who has been selected by the group members, all of whom will use their loans for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Mos Sam, is a construction worker and also a fisherman. Although they work hard with their businesses, they do not earn enough income. Therefore, in order to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Sokhoeun S. decided to apply for a loan to start a new business by buying a cow for breeding. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in a local public school, while the other is too young to attend school or work.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Martin Jesus

texts.es: EL SR. MARTIN ES UN JOVEN AL CUAL LE GUSTA MUCHO LA MUSICA ROCK, EL QUEDO HUERFANO DE MUY NIÑO Y FUE CRIADO POR SU MADRINA, A MEDIDA QUE SE HACIA JOVEN EMPEZO A GUSTARLE LA MUSICA ROCK Y MIENTRAS EL CONSEGUIA MUSICA EMPEZO A VER QUE SU GUSTO POR ESTA MUSICA LE LLEVARIA A ABRIR UN NEGOCIO SOBRE LO QUE MAS LE GUSTABA ES AHÍ CUANDO EL EMPIEZA A CONSEGUIR MERCADERIA EN POLERAS, GORRAS, PULSERAS CON TEMAS DE GRUPOS DE ROCK Y ADEMAS EMPEZO A CONSEGUIR VIDEOS MUSICALES EN CONCIERTOS Y OTROS DE VARIOS GRUPOS CONOCIDOS A NIVEL MUNDIAL. ADEMAS EL VENDE JUEGOS DE PLAY STATION 1 2 Y 3 Y JUEGOS PARA PC, A EL LE GUSTARIA QUE LE PROPORCIONARAN VIDEOS DE GRUPOS DE ROCK DE OTROS PAISES DEL MUNDO PARA SEGUIR AUMENTANDO SU COLECCION, SU TRABAJO ES CONSEGUIR LOS VIDEOS Y HACER UNA COPIA EN SU COMPUTADORA Y PONERLO A LA VENTA A PERSONAS QUE LES GUSTA ESTE TIPO DE GENERO MUSICAL. CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA MERCADERIA AL POR MAYOR DE POLERAS, CDS, GORRAS, ETC. ESTA MUY AGRADECIDO CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Martin is a young man who loves rock music. He became an orphan at a young age and was raised by his godmother. Since he was young, he has liked rock music. As he acquired music, he started to see that, with his love of music, he could open a store. Thus, he started to acquire merchandise such as tee shirts, hats, and bracelets with rock group themes. He also started to get music videos of concerts and rock groups of world fame. He also sells Play Station 1, 2 and 3 games and computer games. He could like to have a greater proportion of videos of rock groups from other countries to augment his collection. His job is to get the videos, make a copy on his computer, and sell it to people who like that type of music. With the money from this loan, he will buy merchandise in bulk: tee shirts, hats, CD’s, etc… He is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust given in granting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Atsu

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un responsable de famille, il a 2 enfants et sa femme est une coiffeuse. Il y a 5 ans il a ouvert une boutique qu’il a appelé « ETS VIACO » dans laquelle il faisait le commerce de pièces détachées Avec le revenu de ce commerce il subvient aux charges de sa famille. Il a reçu de ses clients des commandes qu’il ne peut satisfaire avec son stock actuel, il sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de pièces détachées de véhicules et de motos. Il s’approvisionne au burkina faso
texts.en:
This gentleman is the head of a household; he has two children, and his wife is a hairdresser. Five years ago he opened a shop that he calls « ETS VIACO », where he does business selling spare parts. With the income from this business, he is able to pay his family's expenses. He has received orders from his clients that he can't fill from his current stock. Thus he is seeking a loan through WAGES for the purchase of automobile and motorcycle parts. He gets his supplies in Burkina Faso.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of spare parts

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria es soltera tiene 29 años estudia en la universidad  la carrera de secretearía esta en  octavo semestre, el préstamo  que solicita es para que su mamá incremente el pequeño negocio de ropa de adultos y de niños, sus compras las realiza cuando le hacen el préstamo,  viaja a la ciudad de Guayaquil, su mamá y su papá trabajan en su negocio, las fechas que mas se venden es en los meses de carnaval, mayo y diciembre  su mayor sueño es seguir adelante.

Gloria es soltera pero eso no impide que ella sea una chica que piense mucho en el trabajo  y las responsabilidades, por eso piensan seguir estudiando y seguirá apoyando a sus padres.
texts.en:
Gloria is 29 years old and single. She is in her eighth semester of studying for a secretarial career in the university. The loan she is requesting is so that her mother can increase her small business selling clothes for adults and children. She will make the purchases when she receives the loan. She will travel to the city of Guayaquil. Her mother and father work in their business. The dates when they sell the most are the months of carnival, May and December. Her biggest dream is to get ahead. Gloria is single, but she does no let that stop her from being a girl who thinks a lot about work and responsibilities. Therefore, she plans to keep studying and to continue supporting her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes for women, men, and children

loans.name: Acuario 2 Group

texts.es:
El grupo Acuario 2 está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras, esforzadas y decididas  una de ellas es  Rosa María G. González, coordinadora del grupo quien se dedica a la venta de cerdo y cuajadas ambulante negocio con el que saco delante a su familia.
 Sus compañeras de grupo son Manuela de Jesús Jiménez quien comercializa accesorios en mercado Israel  como chapas, pirañas,   aros…etc. y Rosa Amanda S. quien venta de tortillas e invertirá el crédito en maíz, leña, molino, cal.
texts.en:
The “Acuario 2” (Aquarius 2) Group consists of three hardworking, vibrant, and determined individuals. One of them is Rosa María G. González, the group coordinator, who sells pork and curds from her traveling business so that her family can get ahead.

Her fellow group members include Manuela de Jesús Jiménez, who sells accessories at the Israel Market such as lockets, hairpins, hoop earrings, and other items. Rosa Amanda S. sells tortillas and will invest her loan in corn, firewood, lime, and a grain mill.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pork & curds

loans.name: Chroeng

texts.en: Mrs. K. is a 50-year-old cultivator who resides in the capital, Phnom Penh. K. was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. She now has four children who are no longer in school. To help cover the family’s daily expenses, three of her children work in the construction field, while the other works with her in the farming business. K. owns a piece of farmland located away from the watering system, so she can hardly irrigate her crop. To solve the problem, K. is asking for a loan to purchase a machine that she uses to pump the water for her crops.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for pumping water for her crops

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia C. is from the village of Libona Bukidnon. She is 34 years old. Cynthia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Cynthia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Cynthia has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cynthia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cynthia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Cynthia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Oscar Mauricio

texts.es: Oscar M. vive en Bogotá, tiene cuatro hijos en las edades de 5 a 24 años , desde hace un año Oscar y su socio emprendieron un negocio  muy creativo, es una   alternativa diferente,  para emprender un negocio donde empacan almendras, grageas y dulces en pitillo, organizados en cajas de 50 unidades. Juntos asumieron el reto de dar inicio a ese gran sueño de tener un negocio  a raíz de dificultades  en el ingreso, por eso desde hace un año y hasta ahora, están funcionando con mucho empeño, esfuerzo y trabajo para salir adelante; este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y están requiriéndolo para comprar su materia prima como lo es, las  almendras, pitillos, silicona y stikers con los que lo marcan. Su sueño es comprar una vivienda para generar bienestar a su familia y que este negocio continúe creciendo. Ahora tienen un gran desafío y es precisamente la tramitología de la legalización, ficha técnica, etc. que se requiere, especialmente en lo relacionado  con el registro ante el INVIMA, organización de vigilancia y control y seguramente muy pronto   recibirán asesoría para hacerlo.
texts.en:
Oscar M. lives in Bogotá, and has four children between the ages of 5 and 24. In the past year, Oscar and his partner have started a very unique business where they pack almonds, small candies, and candy in straws into boxes comprised of 50 units. They decided to take on the challenge of embarking on this grand dream to have a business together due to financial difficulties. As a result, they have been working with great determination and effort to get ahead for one year. This is their first loan with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, and they are in need of capital in order to buy goods such as almonds, straws and the stickers that they use for labeling. His dreams include buying a home for his family, and to see his business grow. Right now he has a huge challenge in dealing with bureaucratic red tape, particularly with the paperwork related to registering with INVIMA. This is the government agency responsible for regulating food safety standards and, surely, he will receive his approvals soon.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase items such as almonds, straws, and labels.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a single mother of four children. Only two of the children are schooling; the rest are working. She also takes care of additional family members (old parents).  

She owns a bar in Kawempe, selling all types of beer and soft drinks like soda and mineral water. She has been in this bar business for many years. Sarah wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and soda and boxes of mineral water. She sells both on a retail and wholesale basis and sells to all categories of people. Sarah works seven days a week. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work.  

Her business challenges include defaulters and the rainy season, which hinders her customers reaching her. She aspires to see her business grow big, to start selling only on a wholesale basis and also to get enough profits to buy a plot of land.      

She decided to work with MCDT because of their good customer care and also because they give out timely loans. Sarah resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and food.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda  and boxes of mineral water

loans.name: Señor De Luren Group

texts.es:
El Bancomunal Señor de Luren inicia su ciclo 9 con 12 socias que pertenecen al distrito de Huancavelica, cuya actividad económica principal es el comercio.
Yolanda es una de las socias del bancomunal, este ciclo tiene el cargo de Tesorera en la Junta Directiva. Yolanda tiene 3 hijos jóvenes de 26, 18 y 16 años de edad, Yolanda tiene como negocio una librería pequeña, donde vende útiles de escritorio como son cuadernos, hojas, lápices, todo tipo de papelería; su negocio se inició con poca mercadería, poco a poco ha ido implementando de acuerdo a las necesidades de sus clientes, ahora tiene también una fotocopiadora, hace servicio de copias, ploteo y tipeo de documentos. Los préstamos que recibe Yolanda los utiliza en la compra de útiles al por mayor y en cantidad para su negocio. Su sueño es tener una librería grande y exportar pedidos al por mayor a instituciones de su localidad.
texts.en:
The “Señor de Luren” (Lord of Luren) communal bank starts its 9th cycle with 12 members who are from Huancavelica district whose main economic activity is commerce. Yolanda is one of the members and is serving as Treasurer on the governing board during this cycle. She has three young children who are 26, 18 and 16 years of age. Yolanda has a small bookstore where she sells stationery items like: notebooks, sheets of paper, pencils and all types of paper goods. She started the business with just a few items but gradually has been stocking it according to the needs of her customers. Now, she also has a photocopying machine and provides copying services as well as document typing and formatting. The loans that Yolanda receives are used to buy school supplies at wholesale and in large quantities for her store. Her dream is to have a large bookstore and to be able to fill large orders for all her local schools.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school supplies at wholesale.

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina M. is a 52-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a fruit-selling and general store, a pig fattening business and a farming business. She lives in Purok Mabinoligon, Barangay Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fruits/general store, and in her pig fattening and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of about $210 a month. 

Medina is now borrowing 16,000 PHP so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Medina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Nyamdorj

texts.en: Nyamdorj T. is a 45-year-old married man who lives with his wife and five children in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of his children attend a local secondary school. His wife works in the health sector and Nyamdorj works as a taxi driver. He began his business in 2006 after operating a meat-trading business for the previous three years. His previous business earnings plus his wife's salary have enabled him to buy his own car. Nyamdorj is a very optimistic and hardworking person who hopes to have his own house with a fence for his family. He is requesting a 1,600,000 MNT loan in order to purchase spare parts for his car and to purchase more meat for resale.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Norng

texts.en:
Mrs. Norng P. R. lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province,  She is 29 years old and a farmer, with 3 children who all attend school. She owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family and she also works as a farming laborer.  Her husband, Mr. Sara Neat (pictured), is a fisherman. 

Though they both work hard, the couple earns a low income.  To improve her family's standard of living, Mrs. Norng P. R. is applying for a loan to buy four piglets and pig food to start a new business breeding pigs.  With the remainder of the loan, she plans to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy four piglets and pig food

loans.name: Domidia

texts.en:
Domidia is a 45-year-old pepper producer and mother of five who lives with her family in the region of Upala in the Northern region of Costa Rica, minutes from the Nicaraguan border. Domidia is a dedicated producer and mother. She plans to focus her efforts on the planting and harvesting of Cayenne peppers. She works in cooperation with her family to strike a balance between accomplishing the daily tasks associated with agricultural production and the completion of domestic responsibilities. The land she works is her own. In addition to her agricultural activity, Domidia feels it is important to be an active member of her community. As a result, she dedicates a significant portion of her time to community meetings, groups and events. The rural zone where Domidia and her family live is sparsely populated with infrequent bus service and a general lack of infrastructure. Domidia is working hard towards the sustenance of her family, striving to reap the maximum benefits from her land as well as her labor. 

Although this is an individual loan, the community in which Domidia and her family live is very close-knit and interdependent. Neighbors help and support one another by sharing experiences and expertise acquired over the years. All individual members of the Upala community are dedicated to the improvement of living conditions for the region as a whole.

This loan will be used to finance the production of Cayenne peppers. Specifically, the loan will be used to finance the purchase of a variety of necessary agricultural nutrients, fertilizers and chemicals in order to ensure a healthy harvest. All labor and logistical tasks associated with production will be carried out by Domidia with the help of her family members in the region of Upala. The production cycle (from planting to harvest) for these types of peppers is roughly one year. Domidia expects to harvest in the next eight months. Typically, she dedicates the hours from 7AM to 4PM everyday to her agricultural activities. 

Piper and Capiscum Processors Compañía Agrícola Industrial (PROPICA) is an international buyer and seller of chili pepper and ground pepper products. In cooperation with Fundación Mujer, PROPICA has guaranteed to purchase the agricultural products (the peppers) that are to be produced with the help of this loan. PROPICA acts as a guaranteed client for small agricultural producers in the area of Upala, thus ensuring that their products will reach market. 

The main obstacle Domidia and other producers in the Upala community face, is a lack of access to working capital funds. The collaboration of Fundación Mujer and PROPICA represents a unique opportunity to Domidia, her family and community. By offering a source of start-up capital and a guaranteed client to purchase what is produced, this is a chance to improve family and community standards of living. Above all, Domidia wants to take advantage of the current opportunity that has been presented. She wants to profit from this collaboration and see improvements in her home and neighborhood.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural chemicals and nutrients.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. is a farmer from the town of Kisii in western Kenya. She is 38 years old, widowed, and has one two-year-old child.  Mary has been farming for 10 years and employs one farmhand. Her mixed farm produces milk, beans, maize, and bananas, which she sells at the local market. She depends on the income from her farming activities to provide for the basic needs of her family.  

She has requested a loan of 35,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that her family will be guaranteed enough milk for consumption and her income will increase through the sale of milk. She will, therefore, be able to provide for her needs and that of her baby.

Her primary challenges have been lack of market for her products, high cost of quality-bred cows, and lack of artificial insemination services in her area. She hopes to expand her farming in the future and venture into poultry farming as well.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Clemantine

texts.en: Clemantine is 28 years old. She is married and has three children between the ages of one and six. Two of her children go to school. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Clemantine has been selling beans and sorghum for six years. She is requesting this loan to buy more beans and sorghum to sell. With profits from this business, Clemantine is planning to renovate her house and put the rest into savings. She says that her business is successful and as a result she managed to buy a motorcycle. In the future, she would like to see her business grow up to 90%.

loans.use: to buy more beans and sorghum to sell

loans.name: Rahat's Group

texts.en:
Rahat is a caring lady who lives in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan and known for its history and culture. In order to support her family financially, she does embroidery work at her home, receiving orders from her neighborhood clients.

Her husband’s name is M. T. and he operates a milk shop in the market. He has contacts with different milk providers in the nearby village. They provide him milk and he stores it in the fridge and freezer to maintain its freshness. He also makes yogurt and sells it for a good profit.

Rahat is the mother of three sons, all of whom are illiterate as they couldn’t get an education due to financial constraints. Her eldest son works with his father at his shop. Her second son works as a salesman and the youngest works in bus repair workshop.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband in his business. With the loan, he will buy a new fridge because his current fridge has become out of order. The new fridge will help him provide fresh quality milk and yogurt to his customers. Rahat’s husband has been doing this business for over 17 years and she is hopeful that by utilizing the loan, her husband will successfully be able to improve his business condition. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has established a good credit record and attended every meeting.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Rahat.

loans.use: To buy a new fridge for a milk shop.

loans.name: Erdenebileg

texts.en:
Erdenebileg G. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband is retired and receives a pension. Her son is a university student and her daughter attends a local primary school. 

Erdenebileg operates a meat trading business in her town. She began her business in 2000 and has gained much experience as a businesswoman. She purchases livestock and a large amount of  meat at wholesale prices and sells it as a retailer at the local market. Her earnings have enabled her to pay her son's tuition fees. Erdenebileg is a hardworking and modest person. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to increase her working capital in order to buy more meat to sell.

loans.use: To buy more meat for resale

loans.name: Delia Maria

texts.es:
Delia de 47 años,  es una mujer trabajadora que ha trabajado por sus tres hijos para darle un buen futuro. Por eso comenzó la venta de almuerzos para tener una actividad económica estable y mantener a sus hijos. 

 Viviendo en una zona urbana llamada Orquídeas de Guayaquil (zona urbana, llamada las orquídeas porque en su descubrimiento habían muchas flores orquídeas). Ha trabajado vendiendo almuerzos en su pequeño restaurante llamado “Delia”. Desde muy temprano comienza a preparar la comida hasta que comienza a vender los almuerzos en un puesto que tiene en su casa. 

Para seguir con el restaurante y ampliarlo ella quiere comprar con el préstamo una cocina y sillas. En el futuro quiere tener un local para tener espacio suficiente y atender a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Delia is 47 years old.  She is a hard-working woman who has worked for her three children to give them a good future.  She started a business selling lunches so that she could have a stable business activity and support her children. 

Delia lives in an urban area called Orquídeas de Guayaquil (an urban area called 'las orquídeas' - orchids - because when the place was discovered they found many orchids there).  She sells her lunches in her small restaurant called 'Delia'.   She starts preparing the food very early in the morning and she then sells it in her home.

To continue with her restaurant and to expand it, Delia would like to use her loan to buy a stove and chairs.  In the future, she would like to have premises which would provide her with enough space and to continue serving her customers.

loans.use: To buy a stove and chairs

loans.name: Umurungi

texts.en:
Umurungi is a 38-year-old, married woman with two children between the ages of 10 and 13 years old.  She also cares for one relative. Her husband works in the government, while she sells products such as beans, rice, potatoes, and other products.  Umurungi has been working in this business for about ten years.  Her business is open from 5 a.m. to 5 p.m. most days of the week.

Umurungi will use the requested loan to purchase more beans for sale.  She will reinvest any profits made from the loan back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more beans for sale

loans.name: Falak's Group

texts.en:
Falak is a resident of Jaranwala which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Razabad with her family in a 3-room brick house for the past 10 years. She is 44 years old and married to M. A. who works in a factory for a reasonable income. 

She has given birth to three sons and a daughter. Her eldest son operates a 'pan' (betel leaf) and cigarette shop in the market and the 2nd one works in a marble-making factory. Her remaining children are studying in different classes. Falak herself is a housewife, staying at home and doing her household chores. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her son’s cigarette and pan (betel leaf) selling shop. With the loan he will buy betel leaves and betel nuts and cigarettes of different brands which will help him make more sales and earn better profit. Falak hopes that her son who has been operating this business for more than a year will get more success in his business after investing the loan proceeds into it. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In her previous loan year, she established a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a booklet (called Asasah Passbook) is Falak.

loans.use: To buy betel leaves, betel nuts and cigarettes

loans.name: Kanguka Ukore Group

texts.en:
Jeanne is 47 years old, a widow with one child, who is 4 years old.  Jeanne is the only working member of this family.  She has to work hard to provide everything necessary for her family.

Jeanne is a businesswoman selling fruit and cakes and this business is fruitful for her. Jeanne is also the leader of this group which is called Kanguka ukore. The group contains seven women and six men; most of whom are in the business of selling food products.

Jeanne and her group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses. Once their businesses are expanded, they hope to satisfy their customers and earn more profits.

loans.use: To invest  in expanding her business.

loans.name: Vitelia

texts.es:
Vitelia M. Meléndez   tiene 54 Años y dos hijos en las edades de 28 y 30, que con sus esfuerzos han logrado estudiar y ella confía en que gradualmente sean muy exitosos en lo que se propongan. Ella es una mujer que vive en el municipio de San Jacinto en el departamento de Bolívar, lugar donde se producen hermosas artesanías en telar vertical, como hamacas y mochilas tejidas, que muchos extranjeros y habitantes de Colombia conocen y tienen en sus viviendas y/o lugares de campo. Este oficio es una tradición de los Sanjacinteros, que Vitelia  persiste en darle continuidad, por eso  se dedica desde hace ocho años a la elaboración de bolsos,mochilas juego de individuales para mesas y también confecciona uniformes para estudiantes. 
Ella emprendió este negocio cuando se ganó un premio en dinero y lo invirtió en materiales para fabricar   bolsos, contrató artesanas y   así fue como inició su venta, primero  en el mismo municipio y gradualmente fue abriendo mercados  en el sur del departamento de Bolívar y en otras ciudades de Colombia, como hasta ahora lo hace  cuando   envía   productos  a sus clientes, y ellos consignan el dinero en su cuenta de ahorro.
Vitelia como madre  jefa de hogar  ha sacado adelante  a sus hijos con este negocio, del cual se siente muy orgullosa y ha sido su gran desafío porque sueña con que ellos avancen y tengan éxitos profesionales, por eso da  gracias a Dios porque su situación ha cambiado,  tiene un hijo que terminó sus estudios, es profesor y genera ingresos para el hogar y el otro también trabaja; así todos en la familia se ayudan, por eso Vitelia tiene su casa propia y arreglada con el apoyo de sus hijos y todos sus esfuerzos para lograr ingresos, sosteniendo su negocio que es su propio empleo.  
Este es su primer financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo  y con el comprará  hilo para bolsos, cinco pacas, tela para el forro de los bolsos, correderas, hebillas, inversión que augura éxito, debido a que lo que ella produce, siempre lo vende en el mismo municipio o lo envía a otros regiones del país, donde sus clientes están a la expectativa de lo que Vitelia envíe.  En su negocio cuenta con tres personas que trabajan con ella en su casa, sus productos los vende en los almacenes de la comunidad y también tiene clientes en el sur del departamento de Bolívar y otras poblaciones de la Costa Caribe.  El negocio de Vitelia se mueve muy bien: sus cuentas por cobrar las recupera  semanalmente, la mayor parte de sus ventas son de contado, mientras sus compras de materia prima casi siempre  las hace   de contado, aunque muchas veces no alcanza a comprar todo lo que necesita para responder a sus clientes pues  le falta capital y ella  maneja  una rápida rotación de sus inventarios porque los productos que va terminando los entrega inmediatamente.
texts.en:
Vitelia M. Meléndez is 54 years old and has two children, ages 28 and 30. Through her own efforts, she was able to study and gradually become successful in whatever she pursued. This woman lives in the town of San Jacinto in the Department of Bolivar, where she uses her loom to produce beautiful handicrafts such as hammocks and woven handbags. Many foreigners and Colombian residents are familiar with these items and have them in their homes and businesses. This trade is a tradition among the people of San Jacinto, so Vitelia continues the legacy. For the past eight years, she has been making bags, backpacks, individual table settings, as well as student uniforms.

Vitelia started her business after she won some prize money. She invested it in materials for making bags. Vitelia hired artisans and began generating sales, first in San Jacinto, and then she gradually opened new markets to the south in the Department of Bolivar and other cities in Colombia. Now when she ships products to her customers, they deposit their payments into her savings account.

As a mother and head of household, Vitelia is proud of being able to overcome challenges and move her children forward with the help of her business. She dreams of seeing them advance so that they can become successful professionals. Vitelia gives thanks to God that her situation has changed. Her son completed his studies and is now a teacher who contributes to the household income. Vitelia’s other son works since everyone is able to help. She owns her home and is able make repairs with the help of her children and the income from all of their efforts. By sustaining her business, she is able to keep herself employed.

This is her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she will use the funds to buy yarn for making bags, five bales of wool, fabric used for lining the bags, slide fasteners, and clasps. This investment promises to be a success because Vitelia is always able to sell what she produces in the city or ship her products to other regions of the country where her customers can hardly wait to see what she has created. Her business has three employees who work with her in her home. The products are sold to stores in the community as well as to customers in the south in the Department of Bolívar and other towns along the Caribbean coast. Vitelia’s business has very good cash flow. Her accounts indicate that she is able to collect payments each week. Most of her sales are made in cash, while almost all of her purchases for materials are paid in cash. However, there have been several instances when she does not have enough capital to buy everything she needs to respond to her customers. Vitelia manages a quick turnover of her finished goods so that they can be delivered immediately.

loans.use: Purchase yarn, wool, lining fabric, slide fasteners, and clasps for making woven handbags

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Mrs. Nenita G. lives in San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, married, and has three children who are all in school. Her husband is a fisherman, and his catch is sold to neighbors.

In April, 2008 she became a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and has received several loans. Some of these loans were used for gasoline and fishing nets. Now, she is requesting a loan to buy a variety of fish for sale. She would be happy if all of her children finish their studies.

loans.use: To buy a variety of fish.

loans.name: Ruth Miguelina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal” MOSOQ RUNA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco,  perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Ruth; la socia tiene 42 años de edad, separada y tiene 3 hijos; la socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de ropa en general tanto para niños y adultos, la socia viaja hasta las ciudades de Lima y Tacna para comprar su mercadería para luego venderlos a sus clientes que son sus familiares, amistades y vecinos, la socia lleva ya un buen tiempo en este negocio el cual se siente feliz ya que mediante este trabajo ella saca su familia adelante ya que ella es una persona bien responsable.

La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de más mercadería como polos, jeans, camisas, casacas y ropa para niños entre otros más.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota
texts.en:
Ruth is a member of the "MOSOQ RUNA” community bank which is located in Cusco district, in Cusco province and department.

Ruth is 42 years old, separated, and has 3 children.  She divides her time between her daily activities and her business selling adults' and children's clothes.  She travels to the cities of Lima and Tacna to buy her merchandise which she then sells to her customers who are family members, friends and neighbors.  She has been in this business for quite a while and feels happy because her work enables her to get her family ahead in life.  She is a very responsible person.

Ruth is requesting this loan to buy more merchandise such as polo shirts, jeans, shirts, jackets, children's clothes, etc.  She is happy to be receiving the loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise such as polo shirts, jeans, shirts, jackets, children's clothes, etc.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius O. M. is 39 years old and single. 

He has been running an electric supply shop for 11 years. He was previously working as an electrician. 

He joined Faulu Kenya so that he could easily save his money and access a loan easily. He has requested 20,000 KES, which he will use to buy electrical appliances such as multi-plug sockets, switches and electrical cables. 

He hopes to fully establish his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy multi-plug sockets, switches and electrical cables

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Laxmi F. is from the village of Olingan, Dipolog City. She is 59 years old and married. She has six adult children.

Laxmi owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transportation services to the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In the photo, Laxmi is shown with her husband, who operates the motorcycle.

In 2006, Laxmi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional stocks and products for her store.

Laxmi is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase accessories for motorcycle repair and painting. This will be her 12th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase accessories for motorcycle repair and painting.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 54 years old and married with five children. Teresita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like sardines, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store.

Teresita has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 13 years and also earns income from pig raising.

Teresita aspires to save and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Pedro Antonio

texts.es:
Pedro, es agricultor, vive con su esposa y no tienen hijos, él siempre ha trabajado la tierra, pues aprendió desde muy joven y hoy día es el trabajo que le da el sustento diario.
Él solicita un préstamo para la compra de insumos para la siembra como: abono, fertilizantes y tratamiento para plagas, esta inversión será una gran ayuda para que el pueda ejecutar el cultivo.
Pedro tiene la esperanza de recibir una buena cosecha, que le ayude para poder comercializar una parte y también para el consumo familiar.
texts.en:
Pedro is a farmer.  He lives with his wife; they have no children.  He’s always worked the land since he learned how from a very young age.  Today, it’s the work that provides his daily sustenance.

He is asking for a loan to buy farming supplies like: manure, fertilizer and insecticide.  This investment will be very helpful for him to carry out his planting.

Pedro hopes to get a good harvest that will allow him to sell part of it and use the other part for family consumption.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies.

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
Angela tiene 39 años de edad, es casada vive con el esposo y con 5 hijos de 23, 21, 17, 15, y 4 años, viven en Parroquia San Pablo perteneciente al Cantón San Miguel.

Los miembros de la V.R.C UNION Y ESPERANZA  se encuentra ubicada en la Parroquia San Pablo a 30 minutos de la oficina en San Miguel los miembros de esta ventanilla se dedican a la agricultura siembra de maíz, papas y al comercio ventas de legumbres y otros.

Angela se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz en pocas cantidades siembra papas y tambien se dedica al comercio de venta de lugumbres, este trabajo lo viene desarrollando desde hace mucho tiempo, las compras las realiza en San Miguel y Vende sus productos en San Pablo y San Miguel en las ferias.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas y fertilizantes, el crédito el ayudado a aumentar los ingresos y la producción, ha enfrentado desafíos como la falta de trabajadores y el variación del clima que en ocasiones a dañado los cultivos. Su sueño es comprar mas terreno para aumentar la produccion.

Le gusta trabajar en el campo, tejer ropa de lana y festejar las fiestas de carnaval.
texts.en:
Ángela is 39 years old, married, living with her husband and five children, who are 22, 21, 17, 15 and 4 years old, in San Pablo Parish belonging to San Miguel Canton.

The “Unión y Esperanza” (Unity and Hope) communal bank is located in San Pablo Parish 30 minutes from the San Miguel office.  Its members are corn and potato farmers and vegetable and others merchants.

Ángela is a farmer.  She grows corn and small amounts of potatoes.  She’s also a vegetable merchant.  She’s been in this line of work for a long time.  She makes her purchases in San Miguel and sells her products in farmers markets in San Pablo and San Miguel.

She is asking for the loan to buy seed and fertilizer.  The loan has helped her increase income and crop yield.  She has faced challenges like the scarcity of laborers and weather variations that occasionally have damaged the crops.  Her dream is to buy more land to increase production.

She enjoys working in the fields, knitting wool clothes and celebrating Carnival.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is a caring lady, 57 years of age. She stays at home and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. She is a very good administrator and manages her household work and expenses very well. Her husband operates a cold drink corner in the market. In his shop, he sells cold drinks such as Coke, Pepsi, Mirinda and artificially flavored juices to his customers. His business becomes demanding in the summer season when people prefer to buy drinks. 

Safia has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for the expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy cold drinks and juices in large quantities which will help him to meet his customers' demands on time and to increase his profits. He has been operating his business for the past 5 years and Safia is confident that after the loan investment her husband’s business will grow further and increase his profits. 

In the photo, the lady with a book (an Asasah passbook) is Safia.

loans.use: to buy cold drinks and juices.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is 24 years old and lives in the Jacob Town area. She is married and has one child, age 2, who lives at home. Her husband is a driver.  

For the past five years she has been involved in the sales of oil, rice and other food. She started this business with money from her husband. Her main challenge is the increase in prices and looking after her child while running the business. 

She will use the loan money to purchase more oil. In the future she would like to build her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more cooking oil.

loans.name: Arabela Group

texts.es:
El grupo Arabela lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras y emprendedoras. La coordinadora del grupo es la señora Auxiliadora del Socorro de 42 años se dedica al comercio de nacatamales y chiverías desde hace 5 años. Este negocio lo inicio con la venta de chocobanos, helados…etc. con las ganancias empezó a realizar pequeñas cantidades de nacatamales.
Ella tiene cuatro hijos de los cuales su hija menor  de 16 años le ayuda en el negocio. La meta de Auxiliadora es invertir en otro negocio como la venta de ropa y calzado.
Las otras integrantes son Mayda de 30 años quien tiene una tortillería y vende chiverías y Jenny de los Ángeles de 24 años comercializa desde hace 5 años cosméticos, ropa y perfumes.
texts.en:
The Arabela group is made up of three hard-working and enterprising women. The group coordinator is Mrs. Auxiliadora del Socorro, age 42. She has sold nactamales [a traditional dish-dough, filled with meat and vegetables and wrapped in plantain leaves] and dairy products for five years. She started this business selling chocolate bananas, ice creams...etc. With her earnings, she started making small amounts of nactamales.
She has four children, and her oldest daughter (age 16) helps her with the business. Auxiliadora's goal is to invest in another business, such as clothing and shoe sales.
The other members are Mayda, age 30, who sells tortillas and dairy products, and Jenny de los Angeles, age 24, who has sold cosmetics, clothing and perfumes for five years.

loans.use: to purchase corn, hogs, firewood...etc.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 45 years old and married with six children.

Jocelyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell.

Jocelyn has borrowed and paid back seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for six years. She earns additional income from fishing.

Jocelyn aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 35 years old and married. She is from Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines.  To make a living, she gardens the vacant lot near the house. Various types of crops such as string beans, tomatoes, squash and many others, have been planted. She sells PHP 3,000 worth of crops a month.
Gina wants to expand the cultivated area as a way to increase her income each month. She joined GDMPC this year to realize her desire. Her first loan application is worth PHP 5,000.  With this, she can now acquire a variety of seed/seedlings to grow, and she will use up the vacant planting area.

loans.use: To acquire a variety of seeds/seedlings to grow.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 43 and married with three children between four and seventeen years old. She has been in farming for seven years and currently employs two farmhands in a farm which produces milk, tomatoes, maize, and beans. She runs a retail shop in the local market for additional income.

Catherine has requested for a loan of 45,000 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that the loan will help her uplift her family's living standards by buying pure breed dairy cows which will generate more income.

She reckons with the lack of animal feeds during dry seasons but remains greatful to Juhudi Kilimo for the loan facility.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Juan José

texts.es: Juan José de cincuenta y siete años de edad vive con su compañera de vida y su nieto. El posee una tienda donde vende productos de primera necesidad arroz, frijoles, pan, leche entre otros, su tienda es muy visitada en la localidad pues Don Juan siempre tiene lo que necesitan con productos de excelente calidad a precios cómodos, además les ofrece un servicio excelente; Juan José es un hombre emprendedor con ganas de salir adelante para él la mejor forma de conseguir la realización personal es por medio de la dedicación y el esfuerzo en el trabajo sin dejar atrás la alegría, quiere ver crecer su negocio es por eso que le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar productos para surtir su tienda como granos básicos, bebidas, producto instantáneo, condimentos, aceites, embutidos etc. Juan José tiene la esperanza que su labor le dará la oportunidad de darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Juan José, 57, lives with his life partner and grandson.  He has a store where he sells basic need items: beans, rice, bread and milk, among others.  His store is very popular with locals because Juan always has what they need: excellent quality products at affordable prices.  Besides, he provides excellent service.  

Juan José is an enterprising man who wants to get ahead.  For him, the best way to reach his personal goals is through dedication and effort at work without forgetting about being happy.  

He wants to see his business grow so is asking INTEGRAL for a loan that will make it possible for him to buy products like basic grains, beverages, instant products, condiments, oil, cured meats, etc. to stock his store.  Juan José hopes that his work will provide him with the opportunity to provide his family with a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
Nimfa  is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children.
 
Nimfa has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, breads & beverages. She has had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages to sell.

Nimfa  has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Nimfa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Juan Alexander

texts.es: Juan Alexander tiene 28 años, su actividad es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 9 años que se dedica a este negocio, inicio con las ganancias de vendedor ambulante pues todos los días salía bajo el sol, lluvia y otros factores a vender sus productos. Juan ofrece productos como calzado, cosméticos, ropa interior, sabanas, manteles, entre otros productos.
texts.en: Juan Alexander is 28 years old and his business is selling general merchandise.  He has been in this business for more than nine years.  He started out with the profits he made as an itinerant vendor.  He used to go out every day, come hail, rain or shine, to sell his products.  Juan sells products such as footwear, cosmetics, underwear, sheets, tablecloths, etc.

loans.use: to buy footwear, cosmetics, underwear, sheets, tablecloths and other products

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David, 42, is married to Milka. He runs a butcher which he has operated for twelve years. He was given a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy livestock for slaughtering. He earns an income of 50,000 Kenyan shillings per month.

The anticipated profit will be used to expand his business and to support his family by raising their living standards. This is his second loan from KADET Ltd.

He hopes to become a prominent businessman and a stable family man.

loans.use: to boost his existing business.

loans.name: Uwezo Group

texts.fr: La cliente Lucia, leader du groupe d’affaire «Uwezo », est  entrepreneur, âgée de 53  ans, mariée, mère de 2 jeunes enfants, qui étudient tous. Son mari est un chômeur. Elle est  sociétaire d’un restaurant. Il y a  12 ans révolus qu’elle exerce ces petites activités génératrices de revenus de ce genre. Cependant, elle vient d’obtenir  son  13eme  crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner avec  2 paniers de pommes de terre, 10 litres huile, 25 kg farine, Fanta, lait, etc.  En plus, elle souhaite  voir ses enfants grandir confortablement  et accroitre son entreprise.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique.
texts.en: The customer, Lucia, who is leader of the Uwezo business group, is a 53-year old entrepreneur. She is married and mother to two young children, who are both at school. Her husband is unemployed. She is a member/shareholder of a restaurant. She has been carrying out small-income generating activities of this kind for the past 12 years. Nevertheless, she has just been given her 13th loan from Hekima. She will use this new loan to get fresh supplies: two baskets of potatoes,ten liters of oil, 25 kg of flour, Fanta, milk, etc. She would like to see her children grow up in comfort and grow her business. The customer is grateful to Hekima for its actions in favour of poor women who do not have access to classic banks.

loans.use: to buy two baskets of potatoes, ten liters of oil, 25kg of flour, Fanta, milk, etc.

loans.name: Marta Lidia

texts.es: Marta Lidia D. cincuenta y nueve años D. edad vive con su compañero D. vida y sus hijos en casa propia. Ella posee una venta D. ollas y cacerolas D. todo tipo, es muy conocida en la localidad donD. tiene el negocio pues el producto que comercia es D. muy buena calidad y a un excelente precio, sus ventas siempre satisfacen a la clientela; Marta es una mujer llena D. metas por cumplir y pone su mejor esfuerzo para llegar a un triunfo en el futuro, piensa que al éxito no se le encuentra, si no se le busca incansablemente y ella lo está buscando es por eso que le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar ollas por mayor. Marta Lidia tiene la esperanza que con el arduo trabajo lograra darle a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
Marta Lidia, 59, lives with her life partner and their children in a house of her own.  She sells pots and pans of all sorts.  She’s very well known in the locality where her business is because the products she sells are very good quality and sell for an excellent price; her customers are always satisfied with their purchases.

Marta is a woman with many goals to meet and she puts her best effort into succeeding in the future.  She believes that success does not find us; we must go out tirelessly in pursuit of it and that what she’s looking for and why she’s asking Integral for a loan to buy pots and pans at wholesale.  Marta Lidia has the hope that with hard work she’ll manage to give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy pots and pans at wholesale.

loans.name: Zadock

texts.en: Zadock is a single man aged 31. He describes himself as a hardworking business man. For the last one year, he has been selling ornaments such as necklaces and earrings to make a living. He also does mobile phone repairs to supplement his income. Zadock has employed one person to assist him in the business. In the next 5 years, he plans to establish a wholesale business. He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenya shillings to buy earrings and necklaces for resale.

loans.use: To buy earrings and necklaces.

loans.name: Walter

texts.es:
Walter de 35 años, casado con Nicol de 32 años que fruto de esta relación tienen 2 hijos. Ellos viven en su casa propia ubicada en el distrito de Sivia. Walter es un hombre emprendedor, que desde muy joven supo ganarse la vida.
En un inicio cuando recorria las calles del distrito de Sivia, vio que los turistas buscaban un lugar de esparcimiento donde les pueda brindar bebidas comida que tenga juegos recreativos. Fue estonces que Walter pensó en hacer uno, teniendo ya un terreno cerca al distrito. Es amplio, lo único que me falta es capital, es por esta razón que recurri a MFP, manifiesta. Walter está orgulloso por las cosas buenas que viene obteniendo gracias a los buenos ingresos que le genera su bar. Este será su segundo crédito con MFP, por lo que se compromete una vez más en cancelar puntualmente el pago de sus cuotas. Él esta contento con los trabajos que realizan los miembros de su banco comunal. Con los 2,500 soles, comprará más mercadería y bebidas para abastecer su bar.
texts.en:
Walter, 35, is married to Nicol, 32, and they have two children.  They live in their own house located in Sivia District.  Walter is an enterprising man who has been earning his livelihood since he was very young.

At the beginning while wandering the streets of Sivia he noticed that tourists would look for a place of entertainment where they could enjoy beverages, food and that had games available.  This led Walter to think of opening one since he already had a lot near the district.  “It’s spacious but the only thing I lacked was capital and that’s why I called on MFP,” he states.
